Description:
PM 2.5 refers to atmospheric particulate matter (PM) that has a diameter of less than 2.5 microns. A higher value indicates more particulate matter and along with other factors can generally suggest worse air quality. This data uses weekly sensor readings from a network of roughly 80 active sensors using the Microsoft Urban Air platform. Data use the median sensor reading value for the week preceeding that day's data. To fill in the data, we use an inverse distance weights (IDW) method to interpolate additional data in between different sensors.

You can also select "Weekly PM2.5 Readings" from the data overlay menu below to see the original sensor reading locations. To view the data in 3D click the 'Toggle 3D Map' button above.
Added By: Processed Data from HeRoP Lab, UChicago; Original Data from Microsoft Urban Innovation

Description:
PM 2.5 refers to atmospheric particulate matter (PM) that has a diameter of less than 2.5 microns. We used PM 2.5 estimates from EPA sensors in Cook County and 20 neighboring counties as ground truth. To fill in missing gaps between sensors, we generated a model to take advantage of the multivariate relationship between PM 2.5 and aerosol optical depth (a satellite product). Using multiple air quality predictors (such as vegetation, land use, wind speed, temperature, precipitation, aerosol optical depth, point emissions, areal emissions, and more) we estimated PM 2.5 from 2014-2018 at a 1-km resolution using a three-stage model and neural net, replicating previous work and extending it to the local region. Model performance for this iteration of the model had an R-squared of 0.572 after the first stage with 10-fold cross validation. As the model improves, it will be updated in the tool.

For the site selection tool, we cropped the output to the City of Chicago, and aggregated data to the census-tract level; centroids of 1-km grid were assigned to intersecting tracts. We used the average results from Summer 2014-2018, representing peak PM 2.5 trends that occur on a yearly basis, and prepare it as an individual layer.

Some neighborhoods are warmer than others on average, due to complex built and physical environment features, and this is especially pronounced in the summer months. The Urban Heat Island data displays this effect on a map. NASA routinely monitors surface temperatures across the globe by satellites. We used average summer surface temperature in 2018 to rank census tracts in Chicago by average temperature as a proxy for the urban heat island effect.

Tracts with indices closer to 1 are the hottest areas in the city. Tracts with indices closer to 0 are the coldest census tracts in the city. Suppose a given census tract (Tract A) has an urban heat island index value of 0.25. This translates as “25% of Chicago census tracts are colder than Tract A.” Note: This also means “75% of Chicago census tracts are warmer than Tract A”.

This measure corresponds to logged average annual average daily traffic counts by street segment, by census tract. The final result is then scaled from 0 to 100, with higher numbers corresonding to greater traffic. We use recent Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT) traffic data available as road segments containing Annual Average Daily Traffic (AADT) counts. We cropped the data to the City of Chicago (9,373 road segments), simplified to point locations, and calculated total AADT within each Census Tract. These numbers were subsequently log transformed to normalize the distribution for more meaningful analysis.

Urban and riverine flood susceptibility indices (FSI) identify priority areas across a region for flood mitigation activities. FSI are constructed using a statistical method based on the observed relationship between the distribution of reported flood locations and a variety of flood-related factors. With data assistance from FEMA, counties, and the City of Chicago, the Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning (CMAP) created an address-level database of documented flood locations to cross-reference with flooding-related factors. CMAP’s database consists of over 165,000 unique locations, with the majority of the reported locations experiencing flooding within the past ten years (2007-17). The urban FSI includes all developed areas of the region outside of those 100-year zones.

The Urban Flood Susceptibility Index is scored from 1 to 10, with 1 being less susceptible to floods, and 10 being more susceptible.

The data presented here shows the diversity of plant species recorded by community science platform users in a block group. Some areas have high numbers of reports and some areas do not, and generally, but not always, higher numbers of reports lead to higher reported biodiversity. It is important to remember the biases of collections favoring wealthier, greener neighborhoods with good internet and smartphone access when considering the biodiversity data in this context.

This variable uses Simpon's index of diversity to summarize the species sampled in each tract into a single metric. Simpson's index ranges from 0 to 1 where higher indicates greater diveristy.

Click on a track and then click 'Show Species Tree' to see all species observed.
Data Source(s):
iNaturalist: January 2012-March 30, 2022 GBIF.org (30 March 2022)
GBIF Occurrence Download
Budburst: January 2012-March 30, 2022
Added By: Elsa Anderson & Sophie Taddeo, Chicago Botanic Gardens

Description: This metric describes the amount of tree cover in a given census tract. Data on the location and size of trees was collected by the Chicago Region Trees Initiative in partnership with the U.S. Forest Service. Using LiDAR technology and multiple geoprocessing steps, polygons representing the surface area covered by a tree’s branches and leaves were created. To generate the Tree Crown Density, we summed the surface area of all trees in a census tract and then divided the total by the surface area of the census tracts. If a given census tract has a tree crown density of 0.5, this translates as “Trees cover 50% of the total surface area in this census tract.” A higher tree crown density means higher tree coverage.
Data Source(s): Original - Chicago Region Trees Initiative / U.S. Forest Service/ SAL. Modeled by - HeRoP/CSDS .

Description:
Average Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) value from all pixel values in each census tract. NDVI is a remotely sensed measure of relative vegetation abundance and health using the difference in red (RED) and near-infrared (NIR) measurements. It is calculated:

NDVI = (NIR-RED)/(NIR+RED)

The NDVI calculation produces an index from -1 to 1, with values at the higher end of the range corresponding to greater vegetation abundance.
Data Source(s): Sentinel 2 MSI: MultiSpectral Instrument, Level-1 C

Description:
Percent of adults who reported that a doctor, nurse or other health professional has diagnosed them with asthma, and they currently have asthma. This percent is weighted to represent the population from which the sample was drawn, the household population of adults aged 18 years and older who reside in the City of Chicago. Rates are not shown when their Relative Standard Error (RSE) is greater than 50%, indicating an imprecise and unreliable estimate.

This data is from the Chicago Department of Public Health Healthy Chicago Survey. The Healthy Chicago Survey (HCS) is an annual survey of non-institutionalized adults aged 18 years and older living in Chicago. It was launched in 2014 by the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) to better understand the health and experiences of Chicagoans.
Data Source(s): CDPH Healthy Chicago Survey via Chicago Health Atlas

Description: Annual diagnosis rate for all invasive cancers. Does not include pre-cancerous diagnoses such as breast cancer in situ or urinary cancer in situ. All ages, risk-adjusted. This measure comes from the llinois Department of Public Health, Illinois State Cancer Registry, the only population-based source for cancer incidence information in Illinois. Cancer cases are collected through mandated reporting by hospitals, ambulatory surgical treatment centers, non-hospital affiliated radiation therapy treatment centers, independent pathology labs, dermatologists and through the voluntary exchange of cancer patient data with other (mostly nearby) states.
Data Source(s): Illinois State Cancer Registry via Chicago Health Atlas

Description:
We approximate acute asthma outcomes using the Asthma ED Visits (Age 0-18) data from Chicago Health Atlas in 2017 (Discharge Data, Division of Patient Safety and Quality, Illinois Department of Public Health).

The Division of Patient Safety and Quality collects patient level discharge data from all Illinois acute care hospitals, and the data provide information about utilization and costs of health care services. This dataset contains Number of emergency department (ED) visits among children aged under 18 years for asthma and Age-adjusted rate of asthma emergency department (ED) visits among children aged under 18 years per 10,000 population between 2013 and 2017. The original data only provided the zip-code level data. For our model, we changed its scale to census tract by matching the centroid of each tract with the overlaid zip-code area and merging the data accordingly.

We approximate acute asthma outcomes using the Age adjusted rate of Emergency Dept. asthma visits under 18 years per 10,000 people between 2013 and 2017 from Chicago Health Atlas, as pulled in 2017 (Discharge Data, Division of Patient Safety and Quality, Illinois Department of Public Health).

The Division of Patient Safety and Quality collects patient level discharge data from all Illinois acute care hospitals, and the data provide information about utilization and costs of health care services. This dataset contains Number of emergency department (ED) visits among children aged under 18 years for asthma and Age-adjusted rate of asthma emergency department (ED) visits among children aged under 18 years per 10,000 population between 2013 and 2017. The original data only provided the zip-code level data. For our model, we changed its scale to census tract by matching the centroid of each tract with the overlaid zip-code area and merging the data accordingly.

Percent of adults who reported that a doctor, nurse or other health professional has diagnosed them with high blood pressure (excludes borderline high, pre-hypertensive or hypertension diagnosed only during pregnancy). This percent is weighted to represent the population from which the sample was drawn, the household population of adults aged 18 years and older who reside in the City of Chicago. Rates are not shown when their Relative Standard Error (RSE) is greater than 50%, indicating an imprecise and unreliable estimate.

This data is from the Chicago Department of Public Health Healthy Chicago Survey. The Healthy Chicago Survey (HCS) is an annual survey of non-institutionalized adults aged 18 years and older living in Chicago. It was launched in 2014 by the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) to better understand the health and experiences of Chicagoans.
Data Source(s): CDPH Healthy Chicago Survey via Chicago Health Atlas

Description: Annual diagnosis rate for lung and bronchus cancer. Ages 15 and over, risk-adjusted. This measure comes from the llinois Department of Public Health, Illinois State Cancer Registry, the only population-based source for cancer incidence information in Illinois. Cancer cases are collected through mandated reporting by hospitals, ambulatory surgical treatment centers, non-hospital affiliated radiation therapy treatment centers, independent pathology labs, dermatologists and through the voluntary exchange of cancer patient data with other (mostly nearby) states.

Percent of adults who reported that they did not participate in any physical activities or exercises in the past month. This number is weighted to represent the population from which the sample was drawn, the household population of adults aged 18 years and older who reside in the City of Chicago. This data is from the Chicago Department of Public Health Healthy Chicago Survey. The Healthy Chicago Survey (HCS) is an annual survey of non-institutionalized adults aged 18 years and older living in Chicago. It was launched in 2014 by the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) to better understand the health and experiences of Chicagoans.
Data Source(s): CDPH Healthy Chicago Survey via Chicago Health Atlas

Description:
Economic hardship is measured as a composite index from six measures: unemployment, dependency, education, income, crowded housing, poverty. This index measure compares economic conditions between communities in a more comprehensive way than a single measure could. We followed the original formulation by Nathan and Adams (1976) and use ACS 2018 data (5-year estimate) to calculate.

For more details, please revie: Nathan, R. P., & Adams, C. (1976). Understanding central city hardship. Political science quarterly, 91(1), 47-62.

The Social Vulnerability Index is a composite variable of seven socio-economic indicators that represent an average “rank” of vulnerability, generated by the Center for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC) using American Community Survey 2018 5-year estimates. The SVI was generated from multiple variables demonstrating including: percent of the population that is dependent (0-4 & 65+), percent with a bachelor’s degree (negatively weighted), percent of the population that is white or not Hispanic, unemployment rate, percent of the population with a disability, percent of renters that are cost burdened, and percent of homeowners that are cost burdened. These indicators at the census tract level were transformed, normalized into z-scores, and equally weighted to produce a single estimate. A SVI z-score greater than zero indicates an area is more vulnerable on average than half of the tracts in the study area. Thus, areas with higher scores have more vulnerability.
